turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Mohamed Gad-el-Hak.
turn.1: What is the difference between Mohamed Gad-el-Hak and other scientists?
turn.2: Gad-el-Hak has been a member of several advisory panels for DOD, DOE, NASA, and NSF.
turn.4: During the 1991/1992 academic year, he was a visiting professor at Institut de Mécanique de Grenoble, France.
turn.5: What do you find most interesting about the article?
turn.6: During the summers of 1993, 1994, and 1997, he was, respectively, a distinguished faculty fellow at Naval Undersea Warfare Center, Newport, Rhode Island, a visiting exceptional professor at Université de Poitiers, France, and a Gastwissenschaftler (guest scientist) at Forschungszentrum Rossendorf, Dresden, Germany.
turn.7: Did he win any awards or recognition?
turn.8: Gad-el-Hak is a fellow of the American Academy of Mechanics, a fellow and life member of the American Physical Society, a fellow of the American Institute of Physics, a fellow of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, a fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, an associate fellow of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, and a member of the European Mechanics Society.
turn.9: What else did you find interesting?
turn.10: Gad-el-Hak served as editor of eight international journals, including "AIAA Journal", "Applied Mechanics Reviews", and "Bulletin of the Polish Academy of Sciences".
turn.11: Did he work with any other journals?
turn.12: He is additionally a contributing editor for Springer-Verlag's "Lecture Notes in Engineering" and "Lecture Notes in Physics", for McGraw-Hill's "Year Book of Science and Technology", and for CRC Press's "Mechanical Engineering Series".
